Comments_List: 3 hours

Not so much. 1-2 hours.
2 hr
2 hours
3 hours
Doctoral students may benefit from a more specialized/advanced journal club, but nice to interact with everyone in our dept.
this course is required for EHS students to take - we should receive credit for this course.
The evaluation of JC presentations by a few students was helpful, but the questions for turning in at the end of each JC meeting were somewhat redundant.

In this seminar, professors from other universities are typically invited to give lectures and talks about their own research experience for us, which help us learn frontier knowledge in environmental health science, in the meanwhile, students have opportunity to present their ideas with teamwork.
Strengths: It's a good practice for students to give presentations and fully understand the speakers' research in advance.

This course provides students a good opportunity to learn and discuss the most up-to-date researches in environmental epidemiology and public health from scientists all over the world. In this class, students are required to teach a selected scientific paper and lead a discussion regarding the contents of the paper. By doing this, the students could actively learn and deeply understand a certain scientific topic.
Interesting articles and speakers. However, students do not seem engaged in class which makes presentation and discussion very awkward/difficult
It provides a very good platform for students and professors to communicate with each other.

This course is strong because it couples readings with lectures by scholars who are experts in subjects that align with readings. Given the time of day this course was schedules, it is nice that lunch was provided. However, because this class is a journal club style, it is imperative that students read the papers. The students clearly did not read the papers and therefore discussion was lacking. If students do not read the papers, and do not come to class prepared for an in-depth comment and critique period, that this course become a waste of time.
I think the reading is hard during midterms and finals.

I feel like this shouldn't be a mandatory course as I don't feel like I gain that much from it (it is more of a time killer). I really appreciate Professor Chen, she tries really hard to make the course engaging and is truly one of the professors that cares the most.
Absolutely waste of time, energy, and money.
I like it. I have learnt about some very new research and many different studies in the field of environmental health.
Great for learning whats new in the environmental health research field.
The biggest strength of this course was the journal club and encouraging students to discuss the important literature.
This seminar includes a wide range of topics related to environmental health, but not necessarily of each student's interest. Overall, it's good.
I thought the journal club aspect was very good, and especially enjoyed spending time with seminar speakers after their lectures.
Very knowledgeable, helpful, and approachable!
Dr. Chen is great, could help to facilitate discussions a little better, as students usually have a difficult time in facilitating the discussions.
Ying encourages critical thinking and class participation, and I felt very comfortable to share ideas in the learning environment.
Love her!! She's the best! So easy to talk to and smart
Dr Chen is a patient and responsible instructor, she prepared each class with full materials, and give feedbacks to students on time.
She is kind and organized.
The instructor is very friendly and willing to help. She is thoughtful for improving the students participation and quality of this class.
She's very patient and nice. She organized the discussion greatly and gave us many good suggestions.
good

Dr. Chen is very good at trying to draw discussion from the group. She knows how to read the room and often re-calibrated the discussion based on student's clear knowledge or lack of about the study being discussed.
Prof. Chen is a great lecturer and was so helpful throughout the semester.

She gives insight into our required readings (journal articles) including critiques of the experiments, which was very interesting.
I don't have much to say about weaknesses.
Really caring professor, she tries hard and I appreciate all of the work she puts into the course.
A very good instructor.
Dr. Chen did a good job fostering student engagement and discussion.
Dr. Chen is very nice. She explains the hard/new concepts to the students, and promote critical thinking.
Dr. Chen provided a good framework for discussions and asked thoughtful questions.
required course.
This course is a great opportunity to learn more about EHS topics while interacting with fellow EHS students.
If you are pretty interested at researches in environmental heath science, you will have a lot of opportunities to get in touch with frontier knowledge on this seminar.
It's a good chance to explore various topics of public health and have a peer discussion.

Yes, I would recommend this course to a fellow student, because this course provides students a good opportunity to learn and discuss the most up-to-date researches in environmental epidemiology and public health from scientists all over the world. A student's vision of epidemiology and public health could be expanded by attending this course.
Yes. It can help students learn many creative and interesting lectures and it doesn't bring too much burden.
good
You get out what you put in. Read the papers and be ready to discuss them. If you don't, you will be wasting everyone's time.
Journal club
Just get through it.
strongly recommend.
Yes. The speakers is very professional in his/her research area.
This course is an opportunity for students within the EHS department of interact with one another and discuss relevant and new literature.
It's required for EHS students, so you have no choice :)
This is a great way to become more familiar with current work in the field.
